author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Dancing tampons sing about periods on children’s show
text:
Barnkanalen/Via Youtube A tribute to menstruation will be shown on a children's Swedish show on Friday. SVT/Via Youtube Ths same channel aired animated genitalia in January. Previous Next Enlarge The show that brought Swedish children animated genitalia is now tackling the subject of periods with dancing tampons.
“It’s a thing that happens to girl sometimes. They don’t want to talk about it. Maybe they’re a bit ashamed,” the educational song starts off.
The children’s channel Barnkanalen, part of public service broadcaster SVT, will air the period song on Friday.
In it, YouTube star and television producer Alex Hermansson sings and raps about the normality of periods while strumming a ukulele.
“We are not supposed to notice that something is up. But we know that it is something totally normal. We just need to be extra nice. Show a little patience,” he sings as smiling teenage girls are shown.
Intermixed are dressed up tampons. The costumed absorbents dance like marionettes under a mirror ball after the singer pulls on their strings.
Floating pads hover over the tampons at one point.
Sticking to its theme, the menstruation tribute is heavy on red images, with blood splattering across the scene as the singer explains “it’s just a little blood.”
Barnkanalen/Via Youtube YouTube star and television producer Alex Hermansson sings and raps about the normality of periods. The 23-year-old later sings in front of a mural painted with red droplets.
Hermansson continues: “The body’s working as it should. And that is really, really good hooray!”
The lyrics go on to include some stereotypes of ladies with periods such as “cuddle up, eat lots of ice cream.”
Near the end, the four bouncing tampons — dressed as a pirate, a king and a hippie— are soaked in a container of red liquid as “drippity drip, droppity drop” plays.
“You should be able to talk about the most natural thing, as half the world’s population is involved,” Petter Bragee, head of programing at SVT, told Swedish paper The Local.
It isn’t the first time the channel has caused a stir with it methods to reach children.
Earlier this year, the channel aired dancing male and female genitals in a segment translated as “Willie and Twinkle.”
The racy video, which garnered controversy from parents and an initial adult content rating from YouTube, went viral.
It earned the channel over 6 million views, was remixed and played at Swedish clubs and became a global sensation when it was released in English in March.
"Willie and Twinkle what a lovely pair. Twinkle and Willie living way down there," the English lyrics said.
